Topic.Title: Alaskans are nearly twice as likely to get killed with a gun as New Yorkers

Message.Msg: But they're also more likely to be mauled by bears. Well, if you count tourists anyway, if you count the natives its probably about even. There was one fatal bear mauling in New York in the first decade of this century, and several in Alaska and a frightening number at Glacier National Park along the border with Canada. In comparison during the first decade of the LAST century, when carrying guns into the bush was common, there were only two verified deaths from bear attacks (but many more dead bears). You want your nice safe world, but lets ban all the nasty guns and let the predators come back, let them adapt to the cities, and listen to the howls of the liberals as Mountain lions snack on their young'uns. They maybe they'll realize that the evolution of weapons has corresponded with the evolution of human ethics and the decreased desire for war among the world powers. Nobel was right in one respect and wrong in another. Dynamite didn't make total war unthinkable as he hoped, but Oppenheimer finished the job for him with the Hydrogen bomb.

Topic.Title: Alaskans are nearly twice as likely to get killed with a gun as New Yorkers

Message.Msg: Aye, the less gun violence, but the more you have to worry about other threats. I am "well regulated" as required by the 2nd Amendment, e.g. I train with those of my weapons I expect to use and keep LOAC compliant ammunition for my military weapons. I'm former military with multiple combat arms specialities which means I got lots of "cheap" training from Uncle Sam. Maybe I have a different perspective due to growing up in a house with firearms and a father, a Korean era Marine then an investigator for Ohio Department Natural Resources, who had training similar to what I'd later get in the Army during his Marine Corp stint. Perhaps firearms safety from a young age, NRA sponsored Junior Rifle competition, gun and hunters safety courses prepared me for a more rigorous approach to firearms safety and how I could possible have no had someone die on me by now (outside military service where its sort of the point). After all if one gun in the home kills more, how about a dozen, or two dozen, or however the heck many I have? So, if training IS the big difference (and believe me few police are inadequately trained and most Air Force enlisted personnel wouldn't last 15 seconds in a firefight and aren't usually trusted with automatic weapons), and quality of training does matter, why don't we instead create a curricula of firearms safety and teach a course at every grade level, to eventually include live fire of pneumatic and then rimfire single shot rifles? One people learn the basics of handling, the ethics of use, and the finality of the decision, we'll ALSO see a great deal fewer firearms accidents. As an added bonus the gangbangers in the cities will actually learn to hit each other instead of every innocent bystander in the immediate area.

Topic.Title: Etrade Loans

Message.Msg: at some point, ETFC's loan book will hit an inflection point, and we will start to see dramatic write-ups. however, it is difficult to predict exactly when this will happen, because the loan book is filled with so many HELOCs, which are effectively a subordinate lien to the 1st mortgage, meaning that they have no intrinsic value unless/until the total value of each home exceeds the total secured debt on each respective home. when it does happen, though, I think that we will see an amazing move upward in the stock price. I think that we will hit $50 by the end of 2015, barring any macro catastrophe. I base this on: (1) a huge improvement in the loan book; (2) a general return of retail investors to brokerage services; and (3) a huge increase in Net Interest Margin as the Fed stops artificially suppressing interest rates. JMHO

Topic.Title: America's Fattest States ... All Red States

Message.Msg: 10 seconds of research produce: What is the evidence regarding the President’s statement that “Every dollar we invest in high-quality early childhood education can save more than seven dollars later on”? The one study most relevant to President’s statement is the Chicago Longitudinal Study which reported a $7.14 to $1 benefit-cost ratio (Reynolds, Temple, Robertson, & Mann, 2002). The Chicago Child Parent Centers (CPCs) were highly similar to current state pre-K programs in design and cost, and they incorporated the features of high-quality programs listed by the President’s proposal. The CPCs served more recent and broadbased (though low-income) populations on a large scale and were operated by Chicago public schools. It is notable that the estimated effects of the CPCs on achievement at kindergarten entry are very similar in size to those found for Oklahoma’s universal pre-K program. In the context of the larger literature that links initial and later effects, it is reasonable to draw inferences from the Chicago study regarding the economic benefits of Oklahoma’s universal pre-K program. However, this requires more than simply applying the CPC benefits estimates to Oklahoma without adjustments, and, as discussed below, more recent estimates of the CPCs’ benefits are highly relevant. The $7 to $1 figure is prominently featured in the abstract of the Chicago benefit-cost analysis cited above so it is hard to see how critics of the President’s pre-K proposal could have missed it. Perhaps they missed it because later follow-ups produced higher estimates of the return that are about $11 to $1 (Reynolds, Temple, White, Ou, & Robertson, 2011). Thus, the President did not mechanistically apply the Chicago figure to his proposal to claim that every dollar invested in pre-K would produce the same benefits as the CPCs. He claimed a substantially smaller benefit. As discussed in the remainder of this section, his claim is not mechanistic
